linkTarget.anchoringText: The project involves tying up multiple reservoirs together and separating out the reservoir fluids in the surface network – including the handling and separation of sour gas (the asset has a high H2S content in reservoir fluids). The separated acid and sour gases will be compressed at a high pressure and re-injected into the various reservoirs to create miscibility in the oil thereby increasing its mobility, and to prevent the rapid decline in reservoir pressures. The approximate location of the development in Oman is shown in Figure 1.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Approximate location of the R station development in Oman indicated by the pin. Soure: Google maps.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Approximate location of the R station development in Oman indicated by the pin. Soure: Google maps.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The workflow for developing the integrated model for the asset can be divided into the following broad areas (also shown in Figure 2), dependent on each-other:

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Collaborative workflow to solve the stations H & R Integrated Production Systems Model.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Collaborative workflow to solve the stations H & R Integrated Production Systems Model.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 3 shows the location of the various reservoirs and wells and oil saturation in the entire asset at initial time (1-Jan-2000):

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Distribution of inital oil saturation across all the discretized reservoirs in the asset

formatted-caption.caption-text: Distribution of inital oil saturation across all the discretized reservoirs in the asset

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 4 shows the P-T phase diagram for all the fluids – the 9 reservoir fluids, and the integrated fluid blend used in the surface network. The phase diagram for the integrated fluid is for representation purposes only and is constructed assuming equal volume fractions of all the 9 reservoir fluids. In reality, this will dynamically change during the course of the simulation and field operation changes.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: P-T diagram for all the compositional fluid models used in the asset, including the integrated (blended) fluid in the facility.

formatted-caption.caption-text: P-T diagram for all the compositional fluid models used in the asset, including the integrated (blended) fluid in the facility.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The overall facility schematic has been presented in Figure 5.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Schematic of the integrated facility for the entirestation H & R development.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Schematic of the integrated facility for the entirestation H & R development.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The sweetening unit separates out the sour components and directs the sweet gas towards sales, while operating under a maximum handling capacity. The sweetening unit section of the facility is presented in Figure 6.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Sweetening unit and gas re-injection logic.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Sweetening unit and gas re-injection logic.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The oil production profile for asset from one of the scenarios has been presented in Figure 7.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Oil production profile for the asset from an IPSM simulation.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil production profile for the asset from an IPSM simulation.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The oil production profiles for the asset from two different scenarios, each based on a different way of treating problematic wells with very high GOR, are presented in Figure 8. Such analyses and sensitivities can be performed easily and consistently with this new approach.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Oil production profiles for the asset from two different scenarios of IPSM simulation.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil production profiles for the asset from two different scenarios of IPSM simulation.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In this project, although the work is still underway, many of the challenges faced by typical IPSM challenges were handled efficiently using the new approach. Multiple users and disciplines were able to collaborate using a single tool and share data seamlessly with each other. The fluid continuity was maintained and the reservoir and production systems were truly coupled together to reduce the errors in such system models. Figure 9 shows a schematic detailing the various aspects of this approach (Pathak et. al., 2016).

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Various aspects of the new approach to deal with challenges of IPSM systems showing multireservoir, multi-user, multi-disciplinary, multi-fidelity workflow. (Taken directly from Pathak et. al., 2016)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Various aspects of the new approach to deal with challenges of IPSM systems showing multireservoir, multi-user, multi-disciplinary, multi-fidelity workflow. (Taken directly from Pathak et. al., 2016)
